doc.title: Banks - Brazil
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/BofA/Less bricks the path to efficiency gainsLess bricks the path to efficiency gains_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/BofA
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/BofA

passages.text: Brazilian banks have reduced their physical footprint by c.30% over the past ten years, but headcount fell by only c.10% and opex continued to grow in line with inflation, given investments in tech infrastructure and labor. We now expect the banks to i) realize the operating benefits of the investment cycle, ii) make further reductions/ changes to their physical branch networks, and iii) lower headcount. Our sensitivity analysis suggests that such a strategy could pose potential upside risk of 5- 10% to our '27 estimates and think it would become a major topic of discussion for the sector.

Brazilian banks have about 400k employees and 17k branches, which operate with a heavy and inefficient cost structure. A reduction of this operational structure could be driven by a model composed of i) posts of services (lighter version of branches) and ii) digital product offering. Artificial intelligence should be a key driver for more efficient and specialized apps to distribute products, while boosting NPS. Exhibits 1- 10.

We currently forecast opex to grow slightly above inflation over the next three years, in line with the trends observed in the past 10 years. However, if we were to incorporate reductions of 10- 17% in branches and 4- 12% in headcount through '27, we believe that opex could grow at half of the expected pace or even remain flat in nominal terms. This could lead to an improved industry efficiency ratio of 38- 40% (vs 42% currently forecasted), boost '27E sector earnings by 5- 10%, and increase ROE by 100- 200bp (to 18- 19% vs current forecast of 17%). Exhibit 11.

We expect the private sector banks to be more proactive in their efficiency strategy, with i) Santander having the most room to reduce branches (given less reductions than peers over the past 10 years, but restrained by a smaller geographic reach), ii) Itau the most room to reduce headcount (as it boasts the highest number of employees per branch), and iii) Bradesco the most room to improve the efficiency ratio (which is the worst in the sector). Finally, we think that government control could make it harder for Banco do Brasil to make significant reductions to its headcount.

We ran an analysis with 20 countries from different regions. In the past 10 years, there has been a significant reduction of c.20% in the number of physical branches. The global trend shows that headcount tends to be more resistant, dropping only 5% in the same period. However, the data suggests that countries that have been more active in reducing branches experienced higher efficiency gains. Exhibits 12- 16.
Equity Brazil Financial Services

ECB: European Central Bank ONS: Office for National Statistics SBA: Sweden Banking Association IMF: International Monetary Fund BCB: Brazilian Central Bank CNBV: Mexican National Banking and Securities Commission SBS: Superintendency of Banking Insurance and Private Pension in Peru SFC: Financial Superintendency of Colombia CMF: Financial Market Comission in Chile BCRA: Argentina's Central Bank CPI: consumer price index

Brazilian banks have been making drastic reductions to their physical distribution network in the past 10 years. During this period, the system's branch network was reduced by c.30% (Exhibit 1), while headcount was reduced by c.10% (Exhibit 2), according to Brazilian Central Bank data.
Exhibit 1: Brazilian industry - number of branches (thousands) Number of branches has gradually declined over the past ten years.
Source: Companies. Includes BBAS, BBDC, ITUB (ex-LatAm), SANB

Bradesco and Itau led the way, reducing their branch bases by half of the past decade, particularly during the pandemic (Exhibit 3 and 4). Meanwhile, Santander had the smallest reduction in branches, according to BCB data (about 10% in ten years). Banco do Brasil's branches declined in the same pace as private peers' before the pandemic, but have remained stable over the past five years.
Exhibit 3: Number of branches (thousands) Banco do Brasil has a superior number of branches

Banco do Brasil had the strongest reduction in headcount over the past decade, although it happened mostly before the pandemic. Bradesco's headcount declined about 10% over the past ten years. On the flipside, headcount actually increased for Itau and Santander (Exhibit 5 and 6). Consequently, the industry's ratio of employee per branch has almost doubled from c.20x in 2015 to c.40x in '24. Exhibit 7.
Exhibit 2: Brazilian industry - number of employees (thousands) while the number of employees declined until 2016, but remained relatively stable since then
Source: Companies. Includes BBAS, BBDC, ITUB (ex-LatAm), SANB
Exhibit 4: Number of branches evolution \((2014 = 100)\) Bradesco and Itau closed more branches than peers
Headcount remained elevated, possibly supported by new hirings related to innovation
Source: Companies. Itau reflects Brazilian operations only.
ITUB and BBDC have the highest number of employees per branch
Source: Companies. Note: branches only, excluding posts of services

Even with the reduction in footprint and headcount, operating expenses have been growing roughly in line with inflation. Opex have been particularly pressured by personnel expenses, which are indexed to inflation, while administrative expenses expanded generally below inflation. Exhibits 8 and 9. With opex growing at mid- single digits over the past years, efficiency ratio hovered around c.49% according to BCB data, ranging between 44% and 54% (47.8% in '24). Exhibit 10.

Operating expenses grew roughly in line with inflation over the past ten years due to investments in technology and renewal of infrastructure, which offset reductions in footprint. We now expect i) less investments, ii) reduction in headcount and iii) reduction in footprint, leading to opex growth below inflation and more meaningful efficiency gains.
BBAS and BBDC reduced the number of employees, while ITUB and SANB increased
Exhibit 8: Evolution of operating expenses vs inflationOpex has been driven by personnel expenses, while administrative expenses are growing below inflation
Source:Companies,IBGE
Source:Companies,IBGESource: Companies,IBGESource: Companies,IBGESource: Companies,IBGESource: Companies, IBGESource: Companies, IBGESource: Companies, IBGESource: Companies, IBGE
Industry efficiency ratio ranged between \(44\%\) and \(54\%\) over the past 10Y

Source:Companies and BofA Global Research.Efficiency ratio \(\equiv\) (administrative \(^+\) personnel \(^+\) other expenses)/ (NII \(^+\) fees \(^+\) other revenues \(^+\) tax expenses). Industry based on BCB data for the system.

We ran a sensitivity analysis by bank to estimate the potential upside risk to earnings estimates coming from potential reduction in footprint and headcount. We simulated two scenarios ("efficient" and "very efficient"), which incorporate branch reductions of \(10 - 17\%\) , and headcount reductions of \(4 - 12\%\) over the next two years. We estimate that such a strategy could pose potential upside risk of \(6 - 10\%\) to our estimates.

Bradesco provides the strongest upside, with the efficiency ratio potentially improving from \(c.52\%\) to \(41 - 44\%\) , vs current estimates of \(46\%\) for '27E. We estimate \(5 - 12\%\) potential upside risk to current net income forecasts, yielding ROE between \(17 - 18\%\) vs current forecast of \(16\%\) for '27E. We assume \(15 - 25\%\) reductions in branches and \(5 - 15\%\) reduction in headcount.
Personnel expenses represent a bigger portion of expenses vs 10Y ago
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Itau has currently the worst forecasts for opex growth (7% CAGR between '24-'27E vs peers average of 5%). A strong efficiency strategy could pose 7-11% potential upside risk to net income forecasts, suggesting i) efficiency ratio of 32-34% (vs current levels of 40% and 38% forecast for '27E) and ii) ROE between 24-25% vs current forecast of 23% for '27E. We assume 15-25% reductions in branches and 5-15% reduction in headcount.

We estimate potential upside risk of 6-10% to Santander's earnings forecast, which would yield ROEs between 18-19%, vs current forecast of 17% for '27E. Efficiency ratio could reach 38-40%, vs current forecast of 42%. We assume 10-20% reductions in branches and 5-10% reduction in headcount.

Finally, we expect a softer reduction in branches and headcount for Banco do Brasil considering its government control and the fact that it has the lowest headcount per branch vs peers. We assume 2-5% reduction in branches and headcount, providing potential upside risk of 5-7% to our net income forecasts, which could lift ROE to 15% vs current forecast of 14% for '27E.
Exhibit 11: Efficient and very efficient scenarios
We see potential upside risk of 6-10% to our '27E earnings estimates

Source: BofA Global Research estimates

Globally, bank branches have been reduced by c.20% in the last 10 years, while headcount was reduced by only 5%. We think that the resistance to reduce headcount might reflect investments in innovation and technology development. However, the trend differs among countries.
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

In general, the data shows that countries that had higher reduction of branches/headcount also had higher efficiency gains in the past 10 years. However, branch reduction tends to be easier than headcount reduction which tends to be easier than efficiency gains. (Exhibit 12- 14)

Between 2014 and 2024, for Poland, UK and Germany, the number of branches was reduced by almost half which led to an efficiency ratio gain of around \(17 - 20\%\) (2014 = \(100\%\) ). While for Canada, US and Mexico, which had branch reductions between \(7 - 16\%\) , the efficiency ratio gain was of only \(5 - 8\%\) . For some countries, the impact of branches cut was even higher, such as Greece and Denmark.
Exhibit 12: Branches (x) vs efficiency (y) (10Y p.p. chg, 2014=100) Overall, the higher the reduction of branches, the higher are the efficiency gains
Source: BofA Global Research, companies, ECB, IQ, ONS, SBA, IMF, BCB, CNBV, SBS, SFC, CMF, BCRA

Exhibit 13: Branches (x) vs headcount (y) (10Y p.p. chg, 2014=100) Branches reduction and headcount reduction have a positive correlation. The higher the branch reduction, the higher the headcount reduction
Source: BofA Global Research, companies, ECB, IQ, ONS, SBA, IMF, BCB, CNBV, SBS, SFC, CMF, BCRA
Headcount reduction and efficiency ratio gains have a positive correlation. The higher the cut the higher the efficiency gain.
Source: BofA Global Research, companies, ECB, IQ, ONS, SBA, IMF, BCB, CNBV, SBS, SFC, CMF, BCRA
Efficiency ratios have improved for almost all countries analyzed over the past 10 years
Source: BofA Global Research, companies, ECB, IQ, ONS, SBA, IMF, BCB, CNBV, SBS, SFC, CMF, BCRA
Overall, headcount per branch has increased, as branches' downsizing outpaced headcount reductions
Source: BofA Global Research, companies, ECB, IQ, ONS, SBA, IMF, BCB, CNBV, SBS, SFC, CMF, BCRA

Source: BofA Global Research
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Our price objective (PO) for Banco do Brasil of R$20/US$3.5 is derived from the Gordon Growth Model, assuming a sustainable ROE of 13%, a COE of 19%, and 4% growth in perpetuity. Our PO implies a target '26E P/BV multiple of 0.6x. Our USD/ADR PO is derived from the local PO converted at an FX rate of 5.75.

Upside risks to our PO are 1) stronger-than-forecasted loan portfolio growth, 2) lower-than-expected provision charges and 3) greater resilience on market NII. Downside risks to our PO are 1) government interference at the bank's operations, 2) management execution and 3) further deterioration of the agricultural sector.

Our price objective (PO) for Bradesco of R$17/US$3.0 is derived from the Gordon Growth Model, assuming a sustainable ROE of 16%, a COE of 16.2%, and 4% growth in perpetuity. Our PO implies a target '25E P/BV multiple of 1.0x. Our USD/ADR PO is derived from the local PO converted at a 5.75 FX rate.

Downside risks to our PO are 1) weaker economic activity could negatively impact loan growth, 2) corporate NPL deterioration, and 3) higher than expected interest rates could pressure Market NII. Upside risks include: 1) stronger than forecasted loan portfolio growth, 2) less negative than expected impact from Selic rate hikes benefiting Market NII and, 3) lower than expected provision charges.

Our price objective (PO) for Itau of R$41/US$7.1 is derived from the Gordon Growth model, assuming a sustainable ROE of 23%, a COE of 14.0%, and 4% growth in perpetuity. Our USD/ADR PO is derived from the local PO converted at an FX rate of 5.75.

Downside risks to our PO are 1) weaker economic activity could negatively impact loan growth, 2) corporate NPL deterioration requiring higher than anticipated provision charges, and 3) regulatory changes could be detrimental to profitability. Upside risks include: 1) stronger than forecasted loan portfolio growth, 2) lower than anticipated provision charges and, 3) better than expected insurance results.

Our price objective for Santander Brasil of R$33/US$5.7 is derived from the Gordon Growth Model, assuming a sustainable ROAE of 17%, a COE of 14.6%, and 4% growth in perpetuity. Our PO implies a target '25 P/BV multiple of 1.3x. Our USD/ADR PO is derived from the local PO converted at an FX rate of 5.75.

Upside risks are: 1) stronger than forecasted loan portfolio growth, 2) better than expected NII with market and 3) lower than expected provision charges. Downside risks are: 1) deterioration in asset quality, which could lead to higher provision charges, and 2) slower revenue generation in a challenging macro environment, which should maintain ROE below the COE
